1553323.content:
"Sharing a body... But...." Adrien had reviewed the list, but he was uncomfortable in asking any of them. He could not imagine living the rest of his life, sharing it with a member of his family or a complete stranger. "There must be another way..." He pleaded with his doctor.

His doctor had a pained expression, seemingly understanding Adrien's resistance. "I probably would probably not choose to share my body with anyone else either, but this is your only way for you to live. Granted the other person will need to consent as well, but this procedure will save you."

"And ruin someone else's life." Adrien commented. "They could hold saving my life over my head forever too..."

"You are wise for your age young man." The doctor stroked his beard, appearing to be in deep thought. "Have you heard of a Phoenix?" He asked.

Adrien looked at his doctor quizzically. It did not seem relevant to the procedure that had just been discussing. "Yeah, its a mythical fire bird, right? Upon death, its body burns. It is then reborn from the ash as a baby Phoenix."

"Well, there is one other way, akin to the Phoenix mythos. It is a complicated, procedure, but I will try to break it down as much as possible." The doctor then hesitated for a moment before seeming decided that it was best to tell Adrien. "Rather than grafting your head onto someone else's body, we would gather a sample of your cells and regress them into stem cells, the basic building blocks of our bodies. Similarly, your memories will be scanned and saved digitally. We would then inject your stem cells into a growing fetus of an expecting mother and scan as much of your memories into the growing fetus as well."

"So... I will die, but some part of me would be reborn in a different baby?" Adrien asked, trying to summarize what he understood.

"Yes, that is a fairly concise summary." The doctor nodded his head.

"But what about the baby, that I will be put into. Wouldn't I be killing it?" Adrien did not like the idea of taking another's life.

"No, the fetus... or baby would not die; I will explain a little more." The doctor took a deep breathe before continuing. "You would be implanted into a fetus, a baby, that would... likely not survive on its own, but the addition of your cells could stabilize it, save it's life. You and this other baby would combine, in a sense, and grow together, sharing the same body. You would be reborn with an inseparable twin. Some of your memories should resurface slowly as you age, but there is no guarantee."

"So... this baby and I would be saving each other. We'd grow up sharing a body, with two heads?" Adrien asked.

"Yes, we call that dicephalic parapagus." The doctor explained.

Adrien thought for a few moments, and gave his answer. "Do it! But... with a boy baby."

"Of course." The doctor nodded his head, and he hastily left to prepare.

Over the next hour, doctors and nurses busily came and left from his room. They brought in a machine with two binocular-like eye slots which Adrien looked into for several minutes. He was then knocked unconscious so that they could take samples of his bone marrow, and Adrien never awoke. While Adrien's family morned his death, the doctors were implanting 'Adrien' into an willing and expecting mother who previously had multiple miscarriages. His would-be parents knew of the procedure, and understood how the babies would develop.

Months later at a schedule cesarian section, Adrien and his twin brother Aaron were born as two healthy boys with a single body between them. Neil and Dorthy Gray took their twin sons home the next day. The stem cells that the original Adrien had provided made the twins incredibly healthy. Their parents were told they shared two hearts, four lungs, one diaphragm, one enlarged stomach, one gallbladder, one bladder, two livers, two kidneys, and one set of reproductive organs. Separation would be impossible for the boys, but in any case, their parents were not interested seeing as how healthy they were together.

And so, Adrien and Aaron grew up sharing a body. Each twin managed one side of their body. Adrien's sense of touch was restricted to the right half of their body, and Aaron could only feel the left half. Down the midline of their body, they held joint sensation, their being a small overlap where one twin began and the other ended. The shared sense of feeling also extended to the single organs they shared between them. For example when driving though a winding road, both Adrien and Aaron feel the nausea build in their stomach.

The twins grew up, never knowing how the experimental procedure helped them live. All their parents told them was that they were a risky pregnancy for their mother, Dorthy Gray, as she had never carried a child to term before them. But other than that, they were born as happy and healthy twins. And as the years passed, the original Adrien's memories never surfaced. Even MRIs as children showed no unusual brain activity in either brother. The only unusual part of their growing up was how healthy they were, unlike many conjoined twin pairs. Adrien and James's body developed at an even pace. Each half of their body grew at the same rate, so they remained the same height. They even lost teeth at nearly the same time, in the exact same locations in their mouthes. The doctors felt that their health was in large part due to the extra stem cells donated from the original Adrien, which the twins knew nothing about. All they knew growing up was that they had a built-in, inseparable best friend.

"You giving up yet..." Adrien grunted. His eyes stung from the sweat dripping down from his forehead.

"Not until you do..." His brother responded from beside him. Adrien noticed that he seemed to be struggling to blink back the sweat as well.

He wanted to wipe his face clear, but that would disqualify him from their intense match of Twister. "You guys are so silly." Their little sister, Hayden, giggled from outside his view.

Adrien knew that his sister was grinning deviously at her older brothers' predicament. The kind, polite expression she wore hid her mischievous side well. It was her idea to play a game of Twister while he and his brother babysat her. Even though he and Aaron shared a body, that did not curb their competitive edge, especially with each other. Little Hayden knew this of course, and she found it incredibly entertaining to see her two brothers complete ridiculous stunts to win against one another.

He and Aaron had figured out many creative solutions to determine who would win in games likes this. For Twister, they would, for the most part, count as a single person in a group game. They would work together to keep themselves from getting out until they were the last two participants, and then all bets were off. Whoever's side hit the ground first would be declared the loser. So there he and Aaron were, each with limbs wrapped around their body trying to get the other to fall first. They were uncomfortably lying like a table with their stomach in the air. Adrien had his hand, their right hand, on a yellow circle, and Aaron had his arm underneath their back, touching a red circle. Aaron had strategically placed his foot, their left foot, on a yellow circle, and Adrien was forced to shift his leg uncomfortably over his brother's to place it on a blue circle.

"Wouldn't it be easier... if you just gave up." Adrien tried convincing his brother, though he knew it would not work.

"For you... I think I may win this one..." Aaron responded.

"Your so stubborn." Adrien sighed.

"I'm the one who has to live 24/7 with you... Don't call me stubborn." Aaron said before retaliating against him.

"Ref... Ref." Adrien called out when Aaron began rubbing his prickly chin again his cheek. Neither had shaved, so their faces had sharp, small hairs growing. "He's cheating." He smiled, trying to stifle a laugh.

"Stop it Aaron..." Hayden called, and Aaron stopped immediately. "Okay, left foot to red!" She called, though neither of the twins heard the board spin.

"You're targeting me!" Aaron complained.

Adrien felt his brother's leg shift underneath his own, and he felt their tedious balance begin to shift. He smiled, knowing that Aaron was having a difficult time moving his foot over to that circle. He felt that he was going to win, until a flashbulb seemed to go off in his head. He saw himself in a hospital bed with looking strangers he did not know surrounding him. One of them called him by his name, Adrien. He turned his head to the left. Aaron was not there. He panicked.

The dream vanished, and he found himself lying on the plastic game mat. He felt eyes looking at him, so Adrien turned to his Aaron staring at him. "You okay Adrien?" He asked. Concern seemed to be etched on his face. His sister was peeking over them, seemingly scared.

"What happened?" Adrien asked as he and his brother sat up.

"You zoned out or something. It was only for a few seconds, but your eyes rolled back into your head." Aaron seemed to study his face. "But as soon as it started, it stopped. Are you okay?"

"Yeah, I'm fine." Adrien shook his head, making sure not to smack his brother. "It was just a weird dream or something. My brain must have really wandered somewhere else." His twin gave him a sideway glance but seemed to not want to press the issue.

Hayden became cheerful again, believing them to be fine. In an announcer voice, she called out. "The winner is... Aaron!"

Aaron punched the air with a fist. "Woop, woop." He said, though not as cheerful as he usually would. The two of them picked themselves up, and helped Hayden put the game away.
